Document.Description: The Sandy Recovery Improvement Act (SRIA) of 2013 aimed to enhance disaster assistance procedures following Hurricane Sandy by reducing costs, increasing flexibility, and expediting aid. Key provisions included alternative procedures for the Public Assistance Program, expanded housing resources, and streamlined project reviews. Overall, the act represented a significant legislative update to FEMA's authorities, facilitating more efficient disaster recovery efforts.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency
Describe.Health.Emergency: This act can also be applied to health emergencies such as pandemics to mobilize resources.
Note: Appropriations have expired or are likely to expire by now

Document.Description: The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 (OPA) established strict liability for responsible parties during oil spills and enhanced federal authority to prevent and respond to oil spills in U.S. waters. It created the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund to cover cleanup costs and damages, while implementing stricter standards for maritime oil transportation and response preparedness.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Homeland Security - Coast Guard
Note: Programs and appropriations directly relating to Hurricane Sandy; not part of generalized policy framework

Document.Description: The Homeland Security Act established the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) as a new executive department to prevent terrorist attacks, reduce vulnerability to terrorism, and minimize damage from attacks. The act consolidated 22 diverse agencies and bureaus under the DHS umbrella, including agencies responsible for border security, immigration services, and emergency management. It also established specific responsibilities for information sharing among DHS entities, other federal agencies, state and local governments, and the private sector to enhance national security efforts
Entity.Empowered: Department of Homeland Security
Triggering.Event: Act of War,No triggering event - Capacity Building

Document.Description: The Homeland Security Act consolidated various federal agencies into the Department of Homeland Security to protect the United States against terrorist attacks and other threats. Triggering events include threats or acts of terrorism (such as 9/11), natural disasters, and other emergencies. The act empowers DHS, amongst other agencies, to coordinate national security efforts, manage emergency response, and enhance border security.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Homeland Security
Describe.Health.Emergency:
"With respect to civilian human health-related research and development activities relating to countermeasures for chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear and
other emerging terrorist threats carried out by the Department of
Health and Human Services (including the Public Health Service),
the Secretary of Health and Human Services shall set priorities,
goals, objectives, and policies and develop a coordinated strategy
for such activities in collaboration with the Secretary of Homeland
Security to ensure consistency with the national policy and strategic plan developed pursuant to section 302(2)"

Document.Description: The Post-Katrina Emergency Management Reform Act (PKEMRA) was enacted in 2006 improves the federal government’s disaster preparedness and response capabilities  in the United States. Main actors include the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), state and local governments, and the Department of Homeland Security. It is triggered by major disasters and emergencies, and enables actions such as enhanced coordination, resource allocation, and response efforts.
File: Post Katrina Emergency Management Reform Act
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency
Triggering.Event: Natural Disaster,Health Emergency,No triggering event - Capacity Building
Describe.Health.Emergency:
"develop a Federal response capability that, when
necessary and appropriate, can act effectively and rapidly
to deliver assistance essential to saving lives or protecting
or preserving property or public health and safety in a
natural disaster, act of terrorism, or other man-made disaster"

Document.Description: The US Constitution was drafted in 1787 during the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia, to replace the Articles of Confederation. The main actors were comprised of delegates from the original 13 colonies. The overarching goal was to establish a stronger federal government  and unify the states under a common legal framework.
Entity.Empowered: Congress
Note: Not technically a law, but specific sections are explicitly mentioned

Document.Description: US Code Title 31, enacted in 1874, outlines the role of the money and finance in the United States Code. The main actors include Congress, federal agencies, and the Treasury Department, who collectively oversee budgetary processes, financial management, and the regulation of government expenditures. The code is intended to ensure transparency, accountability, and sound financial management within the federal government.
Entity.Empowered: Department of the Treasury
Note:
US code is updated every 6 years, unclear when this specific law was last modified; DOLR references 31 U.S.C. § 1301(a);

1341; 1342;1517

Parent.Statute: Title 44 of Code of Federal Regulations
Document.Description: Title 44 of the CFR governs federal records management and information policy. Title 44 was implemented to ensure standardized practices in alignment with the Paperwork Reduction Act of 1980. The primary actors include federal agencies, the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA), and the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). These agencies ensure efficient government operations, preservation of historical records, and compliance with Federal transparency requirements.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency
Note: No specific enactment date

Document.Description: The Defense Production Act (DPA) authorizes the President to direct private industries to prioritize and expedite the production of materials and goods essential for national defense. It was triggered by the Korean War (1950) and can be activated during various emergencies. The main stakeholders include the President, federal agencies, and private industry.
Entity.Empowered: Executive Office of the President of the United States
Triggering.Event: Act of War,Health Emergency,Natural Disaster,No triggering event - Capacity Building
Describe.Health.Emergency: "In support of national defense, HHS leverages Defense Production Act (DPA) authorities to build a robust and resilient public health supply chain capable of responding to emergency public health threats. These authorities can be used across the federal government to ensure that the domestic industrial base can provide essential materials and goods necessary and appropriate for the national defense." (https://aspr.hhs.gov/legal/DPA/Pages/default.aspx)

Document.Description: The National Security Act of 1947 created a framework, framework for coordinating U.S. national security, through the creation of institutions such as the National Security Council (NSC) and the agencies such as the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA). The act was fueled by the need for a stronger, coordinated national defense strategy post WWII. The main stakeholders include the President, the NSC, and intelligence agencies. Under the NSA actions strategic planning and intelligence coordination to address threats to national security.
Entity.Empowered: Central Intelligence Agency
Note: *unclear how the military is involved in relation to Posse Commitatus

Document.Description: The Individual Assistance Declaration Factors were revised by FEMA in 2019 as part of the Sandy Recovery Improvement Act of 2019. It established six key factors for evaluating a governor's request for a major disaster declaration authorizing Individual Assistance. These factors include state fiscal capacity, uninsured losses, impacted population profile, community infrastructure impact, casualties, and disaster-related unemployment.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency

Entity.Empowered: Access Board

Document.Description: The 6 U.S. Code § 313 officially establishes the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) under the Department of Homeland Security. FEMA was codified to coordinate the official federal response to disasters and emergencies. 6 U.S. Code § 313 was triggered by the need for efficient disaster response and management, and involves stakeholders such as the President, FEMA, state, and local governments. Actions taken can include mobilizing resources, providing disaster relief, and coordinating recovery efforts during and after emergencies.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency
Describe.Health.Emergency: "develop a Federal response capability that, when necessary and appropriate, can act effectively and rapidly to deliver assistance essential to saving lives or protecting or preserving property or public health and safety in a natural disaster, act of terrorism, or other man-made disaster"
Note:
Footnotes
The military is involved but unclear how Posse Commitatus relates

Parent.Statute: The Declaration Process and Emergency Assistance
Document.Description: This section describes the process for requesting Presidential emergency declarations. It outlines preliminary damage assessment, procedures for requesting DOD resources, and procedures for Governors to request emergency declarations. It describes how FEMA processes declaration requests and how affected states are notified. It also covers federal cost-share arrangements.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency

Parent.Statute: The Declaration Process and Emergency Assistance
Document.Description: This section describes the process for requesting Presidential emergency declarations. It describes how FEMA processes declaration requests and how affected states are notified. It also covers federal cost-share arrangements.
Entity.Empowered: Executive Office of the President of the United States

Parent.Statute: Public Assistance Grant Administration, Eligibility, and Insurance Requirements
Document.Description: This section outlines the purpose of the Public Assistance Program, detailing the process for applying for Public Assistance and types of grants available. It covers insurance requirements heavily, stating that facilities in Special Flood Hazard Areas must maintain flood insurance, the Regional Administrator determines insurance for non-flood disasters, insurance proceeds are deducted from eligible costs, and insurance requirements may be waived for projects under $5000.
File:
"Public Assistance
Grant Administration, Eligibility, and Insurance Requirements"
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency

Document.Description: This part implements section 324 of the Stafford Act, specifically management cost funding in disaster relief. It establishes FEMA as responsible for providing up to 3.34% of the federal share for Public Assistance program costs, and up to 4.89% of the federal share for Hazard Mitigation Grant Program costs.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency
Note: unclear date of enactment and update

Document.Description: This part outlines the Fire Management Assistance Grant Program under FEMA. This program provides federal assistance to states, local governments, and tribes for mitigation and management of fires. It outlines eligibility, grant types, applications, and fire cost thresholds.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency

Parent.Statute: The Sandy Recovery Improvement Act of 2013 (SRIA)
Document.Description: This act was aimed at improving disaster recovery efforts in the wake of Hurricane Sandy. Main objectives include: reducing costs, increasing flexibility in disaster assistance, expediting aid, and providing financial incentives for efficient project completion. It provided Public Assistance Program reforms, individual assistance improvements, hazard mitigation grant program changes, and has led to long term sustainability and better positioning of the nation to handle large-scale disasters.
File: The Sandy Recovery Improvement Act of 2013 (SRIA)
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency

Parent.Statute: the Federally Recognized Indian Tribe List Act of 1994
Document.Description: This document recognizes and lists the Native American tribes in the US. It outlines that Congress has plenary authority over Indian Affairs, Congress cannot terminate recognized tribes, and the US must recognize the tribes and their governmental system. It also mandates that the Secretary of the Interior must publish a list of all federally recognized tribes.
File: Federally Recognized Indian Tribe List Act of 1994
Entity.Empowered: Department of the Interior - Bureau of Indian Affairs

Document.Description: This document increased the spending caps for defense and non-defense discretionary spending in 2018 & 2019. It suspended the debt ceiling until March 1, 2019, allocating funds for hurricane relief, narrowing imposed taxes and extending tax breaks. It expanded federal funding towards social services and child welfare, and made changes to the Medicare/Medicaid programs.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency

Document.Description: This act established the National Flood Insurance Program, which provides flood insurance to prone areas. Flood insurance became available to property owners who adopted floodplain management ordinances, prone properties with federally-backed mortgages, and gave subsidized rates to existing buildings in prone areas. It established the Federal Insurance Administration and created a program fund in the Treasury.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency - National Flood Insurance Program

Entity.Empowered: Department of Transportation

Parent.Statute: Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness and Advancing Innovation Act (PAHPAIA)
Document.Description: This law broadly addresses the national security threat of disease outbreaks through an array of powers aimed toward enhancing pandemic preparedness and response during health emergencies. This law specifically includes provisions on the movement of military healthcare workers operating in trauma centers, and the development and distribution of medical countermeasures.
File: Pandemic and All-Hazards Preparedness and Advancing Innovation Act (PAHPAIA)
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services - Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Triggering.Event: Health Emergency,No triggering event - Capacity Building
Describe.Health.Emergency:
Capacity Building for health security
Any health event/emergency that threatens national security of the US
Source: National Disaster Medical System [NDMS] and National Medical Surge
Note:
(Sec. 204) This section establishes a grant program for eligible trauma centers to train and support military trauma care providers at such centers.
(Sec. 701) This section extends through FY2023 specified programs including the Department of Veterans Affairs emergency preparedness program and the tracking and distribution of vaccines during an influenza pandemic.

Parent.Statute: Title 44 of CFR Emergency Management and Assistance
Document.Description: 44 CFR governs emergency management and assistance activities in the United States, ensuring uniform application of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act (Stafford Act). It outlines the procedures and requirements for federal disaster assistance, including the implementation of hazard mitigation planning, the operation of various FEMA grant programs, and the coordination of emergency response efforts between federal, state, local, tribal, and territorial governments
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency

Document.Description: Empowers HHS Secretary to determine when information on potential supply disruptions of a device is needed during or before a public health emergency and requires manufacturers to notify the Secretary of any manufacturing interruptions likely to cause significant supply disruptions in the U.S. during such emergencies, such as PHE outlined in section 319.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Describe.Health.Emergency: If the Secretary determines after consultation with health officials that: "(1) a disease or disorder presents a public health emergency; or (2) (2)a public health emergency, including significant outbreaks of infectious diseases or bioterrorist attacks, otherwise exists," then a public health emergency may be declared under the PHSA.
Note: *not sure what the triggers are, in the code itself it seems like the triggers are increased demand, resource reallocation, and manufacturing disruptions, but it also mentions health emergencies without further clarification

Note: *unclear on whether there is or is not a state trigger, I think that there isn't one based off my current research, however, Cornell Legal Info Institute alludes to the potential for state triggers

Document.Description: Defines "Urgent or emergency public health care need" as a health care need determined by the HHS Secretary due to presidentially declared national emergency, emergencies declared under the Stafford act, PHE determined by Section 319, or emergencies deemed appropriate by the HHS Secretary for deploying the Commissioned Corps of the Public Health Service.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Triggering.Event: Presidential Emergency Declarations,Health Emergency,Presidential Major Disaster Declaration
Describe.Health.Emergency: "Urgent or emergency public health care need" as determined by the Secretary, arising as the result of— (A) a national emergency declared by the President under the National Emergencies Act ( 50 U.S.C. 1601 et seq.); (B) an emergency or major disaster declared by the President under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act ( 42 U.S.C. 5121 et seq.); (C) a public health emergency declared by the Secretary under section 247d of this title ; or (D) any emergency that, in the judgment of the Secretary, is appropriate for the deployment of members of the Corps"

Document.Description: Authorizes the HHS Secretary to contract with fiscal agents to determine payment  for individuals/agencies providing health services on behalf of the Public Health Service.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: Empowers the HHS Secretary to utilize the Infectious Diseases Rapid Response Reserve Fund during infectious disease emergencies declared as public health emergencies under Section 319, or for emergencies the Secretary believes can adversely impact US national security of US citizens' lives.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services - Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Describe.Health.Emergency: If the Secretary determines after consultation with health officials that: "(1) a disease or disorder presents a public health emergency; or (2) (2)a public health emergency, including significant outbreaks of infectious diseases or bioterrorist attacks, otherwise exists," then a public health emergency may be declared under the PHSA.
Funding.Stream.Description: the Infectious Diseases Rapid Response Reserve Fund

Parent.Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document.Description: This provision states that, any individual that seeks care in a federally funded hospital with an emergency department must be examined to determine if the individual seeking care has an emergency medical condition. This appropriate screening must take place regardless of an individual's insurance status.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)

Document.Description: If the President declares a national emergency or if allowed by law, the Secretary of a military department can call any member or unit of the Ready Reserve to active duty for up to 24 months even without their consent. During this period, the President can also suspend certain laws related to promotion, retirement, or separation for those crucial to national security.

Parent.Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document.Description: In the case that an individual arrives at a federally funded hospital with an emergency department and is determined to have an emergency medical condition, the hospital is obligated to provide stabilizing treatment at the hospital and/or transfer of the individual to another medical facility. Guidelines for the transfer of patients is governed under 42 U.S.C. § 1395dd (c). Stabilizing care and/or transfer must be provided by the hospital regardless of patient insurance status.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Parent.Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document.Description: In the event that a hospital offers a patient with an emergency medical condition an option to transfer to another medical facility, but the individual refuses such a transfer, the hospital must take all reasonable steps to confirm written informed consent to refuse this option.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Parent.Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document.Description:
Section c outlines the responsibilities of the hospital at which a patient with an emergency medical condition arrived before that patient may be transferred. According to section (c)(1), a patient must be stabilized before being transferred to another medical facility unless: (A(i) the individual seeking care requests in writing a transfer to a different facility after being informed of the hospital's responsibility to provide care; (ii) a physician certifies that the medical benefits derived from a transfer outweigh the risks to the patient or the fetus of a pregnant person; (iii) in the event a physician is not present, a qualified medical person certifies the transfer as described in (ii) after consultation with a physician. 
The transfer must also be deemed to be appropriate.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Parent.Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document.Description:
Section c outlines the responsibilities of the hospital at which a patient with an emergency medical condition arrived before that patient may be transferred. Paragraph 2 states that an appropriate transfer must meet the following criteria: 
A. The transferring hospital can provide the medical treatment to the individual in a manner that minimizes the risk to an individual, and potentially a fetus' life. 
B. The receiving facility has the capacity and personnel to treat the patient and has agreed to accept the case and provide appropriate care. 
C. The transferring hospital sends all medical records and documents related to the emergency medical condition and patient to the receiving hospital
D. All necessary and appropriate life support measures are utilized during patient transfer
E. Meets any other requirements required by the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Parent.Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document.Description: Facilities that have specialized capabilities or facilities may not refuse to accept an appropriate transfer of a patient that requires such specialized treatment so long as the hospital has the capacity to treat the individual.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Parent.Statute: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Document.Description: A hospital may not delay appropriate medical screening for emergency medical conditions or treatment for such a condition in order to inquire about the individual's insurance status or intended payment method.
File: Examination and treatment for emergency medical conditional and women in labor (EMTALA)
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: Requires the HSS Secretary to develop and regularly evaluate progress on  a National Health Security Strategy to coordinate and improve public health and medical preparedness and response capabilities for emergencies, including natural disasters, bioterrorism, and other public health threats. The National Health Strategy shall include preparedness goals to develop and sustain Federal, State, local and tribal health security capabilities. Also requires continuity of operations and countermeasures to be part of plan.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: Requires HHS to conduct studies to evaluate the feasibility of improving the capacity of the Department of Health and Human Services to provide additional medical surge capacity to local communities during PHEs. Requires MOUs in the event of a public health emergency with respect to each facility for use in a public health emergency
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: Creates the position of Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response. The ASPP is responsible for leading and coordinating public health and medical emergency preparedness and response efforts. This person is responsible for: personnel, countermeasures, coordination of Federal, State, local and tribal integrated responses, identification of inefficiencies, coordinating grants and agreements, drills and operational exercises, threat awareness, medical product and supply capacity planning, logistics, leadership, and countermeasure budget plan. Requires a "Public Health emergency Countermeasures Enterprise," and national advisory committees on children, seniors, and individuals with disabilities during disasters.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: Establishes the National Disaster Medical System (NDMS), designed to provide health services, health-related social services, and other appropriate services to respond to the PHEs, including the movement and definitive care of patients. The NDMS shall test for mobilization of system, consider at risk populations, create a medical surge capacity strategic plan, carry out participation agreements for non-Federal entities, and appoint individuals to serve as intermittent disaster-response personnel
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Describe.Health.Emergency: NDMS may be used to provide health services as applicable ("whether or not deemed to be a public health emergency")
Funding.Stream.Description: there are authorized to be appropriated $57,400,000 for each of fiscal years 2019 through 2023.

Parent.Statute: Targeted liability protections for pandemic and epidemic products and security countermeasures
Document.Description: This section outlines the actions that may be taken after the declaration of a Public Health Emergency by the Secretary. After such a declaration, the Secretary may require the manufacture, development, testing, distribution, administration, and use of medical countermeasures (MCM). The Secretary must describe the following in the declaration: (A) threats to health for which the MCM may be used, (B) period of time in which the declaration is in effect, (C) Population(s) for which the administration and/or use of MCM is applied, (D) geographic areas for which the declaration is in effect, and (E) specifications for distributing and obtaining the MCM. Importantly, there is a provision related to the Strategic National Stockpile (SNS), which requires that, if the MCM is included in the Secretary's declaration, the declaration shall include a period when the MCM is administered or used with respect to distribution and/or release from the SNS.
File: Targeted liability protections for pandemic and epidemic products and security countermeasures
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Describe.Health.Emergency: Declaration of a Public Health Emergency

Document.Description: This EO issued by Truman creates a framework for federal disaster relief for the US. The Federal Civil Defense Administrator (now FEMA) is authorized to provide assistance during major disasters, plan and coordinate for such instances, and prepare rules and regulations for engagement. This order also highlights the integral role of state and local authorities, indicating that federal financial contributions must be conditioned upon reasonable state and local expenditures. However, the order states that, in the event of a major disaster for which response cannot be delayed, federal agencies may provide immediate assistance and will be coordinated by FEMA (previously Federal Civil Defense Administrator).
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency
Note:
For Heather - Says major disaster, but before Stafford
-empowers Federal Civil Defense Administrator - since incorporated into FEMA

Document.Description: This executive order creates the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), consolidating disparate federal emergency management and response entities under a single agency. The order transfers functions from other departments into FEMA and outlines the roles and responsibilities of the new agency.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency

Document.Description: The President can change rules for any device emitting electromagnetic radiation, close radio stations, or allow government control over them during a war, public disaster, or national emergency, with fair compensation to owners.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Communications Commission

Document.Description: This EO creates the Office of Homeland Security (OHS) and the Homeland Security Council (HSC) to enhance national security coordination. The order states that the function of OHS will be to coordinate executive branch efforts to holistically prepare for and respond to terrorist threats and facilitate cooperation with other agencies and subnational jurisdictions. Additionally, this order states that, in the event of terrorist attacks, the Director of OHS will be the primary coordinator for domestic response efforts.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Homeland Security

Document.Description: This EO was created to bolster the US defense to biological attack. The order established requirements to plan and prepare for provision of medical countermeasures (MCMs) to the American citizens in the event of a biological attack. The order requires interagency coordination, cooperation through levels of governance and planning for continuity of operations. Finally, the document mandates the development of a federal rapid response mechanism to dispense MCMs following a deliberate biological event.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Homeland Security

Document.Description: This EO establishes the Global Health Security Agenda (GHSA) as a central initiative to the United States' mission of enhancing global capacity to prevent, detect and respond to infectious disease threats. The order states that the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) will coordinate US governmental efforts to implement GHSA, establishes an interagency review council for policy guidance and coordination and requires an annual report be submitted by the council to the President. The order emphasizes the importance of interagency, multi-sectoral and international collaborations.
Entity.Empowered: Department of State

Document.Description: This PPD broadly directs the government to strengthen security measures across a litany of threats, including public health threats. The directive mandates the development of a national preparedness goal to secure the nation and establishes a National Preparedness System to build the capacity required for achievement of the national preparedness goal. All information regarding progress and system capacity will be included in an annual National Preparedness Report.

Document.Description: This EO was created consolidate disaster response under a single entity within the executive agencies. This entity, the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) was created to improve efficiency and coordination between offices tasked with responding to emergency incidents. Functions previously housed under the Department of Defense, Department of Housing and Urban Development and various other agencies were pulled into FEMA, which was broadly tasked with federal emergency preparedness, mitigation, response and recovery efforts.
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency

Document.Description: This EO leverages the Defense Production Act and empowers the Secretary of Homeland Security and Health and Human Services Secretaries to more effectively respond to the COVID-19 pandemic by allowing them to guarantee loans, make purchases, and take other steps to expand domestic production of health and medical resources needed to combat COVID-19. The EO also allows the secretaries to establish voluntary agreements and advisory committees to support these efforts.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: This EO empowered the Secretaries of Defense and Homeland Security to activate National Guard and Individual Ready Reserve members for up to two years to support the COVID-19 response efforts. The authority for this order is derived from 10 USC § 121 and § 12302. The order allows for the activation of up to one million members of the Reserve and will be coordinated and commanded by the secretaries of Defense and Homeland Security.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: This EO was intended to improve rural health and expand telehealth access as a response mechanism to challenges highlighted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The order required the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to develop and innovative payment model for such telehealth visits, and in conjunction with the Secretary of Agriculture, to develop and implement a strategy to improve physical and communications healthcare infrastructure in rural areas within the United States. Finally, HHS was tasked with proposing regulations to extend the measures implemented to increase access to telehealth services during COVID-19 beyond the emergency period.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: This EO was empowered the HSS Secretary to combat the hoarding and price gouging of essential medical supplies and equipment during the COVID-19 pandemic. The order requires the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to create a list of essential medical countermeasures and critical inputs and the Secretary of Defense to identify vulnerabilities in the supply chain for such products. The order also focuses on increasing domestic production of critical products by directing agencies involved in product procurement to prioritize domestic production and encourage US based manufacturing of pharmaceuticals. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) was also tasked with streamlining requirements to facilitate and expedite the domestic production of critical inputs to these products.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Note: *not entirely sure if this falls within the scope of our project, so airing on the side of caution

Document.Description: This EO empowered the Heath and Human Services (HHS) Secretary to prioritize American access to safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines developed or procured by the U.S. government. The order specifically directs the HHS to prioritize access of COVID-19 vaccines developed or procured by the US government for American citizens over other populations. The order requires that vaccines be distributed and administered in an efficient and equitable fashion. After all Americans have access to COVID-19 vaccines, the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) may coordinate with international partners to facilitate international access to COVID-19 vaccines.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: This EO established a new coordinated federal response to the COVID-19 pandemic by creating the positions of COVID-19 Response Coordinator and Deputy Coordinator within the Executive Office of the President, tasked with advising the President and coordinating the national response, including addressing disparities in treatment and ensuring timely vaccine distribution.
Entity.Empowered: Executive Office of the President of the United States - Coordinator of the COVID-19 Response

Document.Description: This EO was aimed at shifting federal environment and public health policy by directing federal agencies to review and address federal regulations and actions taken during the previous four years that conflict with national objectives to improve public health and the environment (amongst other objectives).

Document.Description: Requires HHS to carry out a program to periodically conduct public health surveillance activities relating to a bioterrorism attack or other health emergency to test new and emerging technologies. Must consult with public, nonprofit, and private entities and must report to Congress.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: HHS must monitor emerging concerns for at-risk individuals, oversee the implementation of preparedness goals with respect to them, evaluate communication methods, and provide guidance to ensure that State and local health grant recipients take them into account. They must also ensure that the strategic national stockpile takes into account at-risk populations and also curriculum for public health and medical response training.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: HHS shall provide guidance and technical assistance to federally-funded health programs and activities, as well as to State and local health departments to better meet the needs of populations served by the above. They may also encourage employees at these health centers to participate in emergency response programs like NDMS and the Volunteer Medical Reserve Corps.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: HHS through CDC shall establish a grant program to award State, local, and tribal health departments, as well as academic centers, for surveillance and response to infectious diseases. It authorizes appropriations for this purpose.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Funding.Stream.Description: Appropriation of $190,000,000 for each fiscal year 2019-2023

Document.Description: HHS through CDC shall establish a grant program to award State, local, and tribal health departments, as well as academic centers, for surveillance and response to infectious diseases. It authorizes appropriations for this purpose.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services - Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Funding.Stream.Description: Appropriation of $190,000,000 for each fiscal year 2019-2023

Document.Description: CDC may enter into cooperative agreements with health departments or political subdivisions in States and Tribal areas at high risk of vector-borne diseases. The purpose is to increase capacity to "identify, report, prevent, and respond to such diseases and related outbreaks." Authorizes appropriations.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Describe.Health.Emergency: Must be an area that is vulnerable to vector-borne diseases
Funding.Stream.Description: Appropriates funding for coordination and cooperation

Document.Description: CDC may enter into cooperative agreements with health departments or political subdivisions in States and Tribal areas at high risk of vector-borne diseases. Describe.Health.Emergency: Must be an area that is vulnerable to vector-borne diseases

Document.Description: Requires the CDC to expand, modernize and improve public health data systems as they relate to preparedness for public health emergencies.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services - Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Funding.Stream.Description: Appropriates funds through 2025 for data improvement efforts

Document.Description: Requires the CDC to expand, modernize and improve public health data systems as they relate to preparedness for public health emergencies.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: Establishes the National Vaccine Program to "achieve optimal prevention against adverse reactions to vaccines." This program is responsible for development, safety, licensing, distribution, and evaluation, as well as coordinating government and non-government activities and funding federal agencies. Requires the preparation and implementation of a plan.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Funding.Stream.Description: Funds vaccine programs administered by federal and state governments

Document.Description: Creates up to 20 eligible high-acuity trauma centers to enable military trauma teams to provide trauma and related acute care on a full-time basis. Includes grant funding. When there is a public health emergency, the grant recipient shall agree to allow their providers to be deployed for military operations, for training, or for response to a mass casualty event and be deployed by the Secretary of Defense in response to a public health emergency.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Defense
Triggering.Event: PHSA Emergency Declaration,Natural Disaster,Act of War,Terrorism,Declaration of War,Health Emergency
Describe.Health.Emergency: "As a condition of receipt of a grant under this section," grant recipients shall agree to certain conditions if there is a declared PHSA emergency or mass casualty incident.
Funding.Stream.Description: Funds grants for military high-acuity trauma centers (up to 20)

Document.Description: Grants to eligible entities for the improvement of emergency services, with specific reference to improving trauma care in rural areas
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Funding.Stream.Description: Grants to eligible entities who are involved in: (1) improving rural trauma systems or (2) improving emergency services more generally

Document.Description: CDC shall develop infectious disease and outbreak analysis capabilities to "enhance the prediction, modeling, and forecasting of potential public health emergencies and other infectious disease outbreaks," including activities to prepare for such emergencies. Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: Revises Medicare Advantage (Part C) and Part D (prescription) plans to implement special requirements during disasters or public emergencies. During times of emergency or disaster, MA plans must cover services provided by non-contracted providers and waive gatekeeper referral requirements. The rule clarifies that MA organizations must comply with these requirements for the entire time that there is disruption to health care access.
File: Medicare Program - Policy and Regulatory Revisions in Response to the COVID–19 Public Health Emergency
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Triggering.Event: Presidential Emergency Declarations,Presidential Major Disaster Declaration,PHSA Emergency Declaration,Governor or Protectorate Emergency Declaration
Describe.Health.Emergency:
"A declaration of a disaster or emergency will identify the geographic area affected by the event and may be made as one of the following:
(i) Presidential declaration of a disaster or emergency under the either of the following:
(A) Stafford Act.
(B) National Emergencies Act.
(ii) Secretarial declaration of a public health emergency under section 319 of the Public Health Service Act.
(iii) Declaration by the Governor of a State or Protectorate."
42 CFR Part 422 Subpart C (up to date as of 7-31-2024).pdf (https://v5.airtableusercontent.com/v3/u/32/32/1725645600000/6pr8fbIy5C_nLZ84HrrVIQ/2ovUIvblKWpQNjjRX2YM3aQEd_0iHIyibSt1eXP7YuTa0s5rjwIalO3zJoGTigdDzJZWnlfJK7MYZpHC3IATp8ItDlbOi_Gm2hxBkJdXzqswkl1b-a_ImXf8qjpY_T31Xa4E_TViH9W9qWN1YfFGSF9Ji2bYg9FcihYkL006ng3qnX9zaiq89CINZFhtPGdkY13831r832NxkgfCZmPqBQ/HkPBw0Tb72gzxyXN0AUFO5z-mUUvwgpiYkEC6Qgd6xU),2022-09375.pdf (https://v5.airtableusercontent.com/v3/u/32/32/1725645600000/wv4fGTPW_Cs5M3dOhXBkjA/VH_CzqPAs7bTWt9ftt81rCVjii1eoF_hWVy6a5e99TeKz_PgU5vG-weuBwJ5HQBq746Lg69wEcqD12cmE31o0u4y0-vWq7j95wxCsuV-q9NUWvuLWevR836AwYa9BaaswytqjC_pdu8lj4vMwFuTjE4ehuZEzzOPXnZ5h9akJtk/TFy9av1K6N7hzlRfocfKkHssRYlxsP4N1hnG0_LQ0Sk)
Note: I put that it was out of 1a because it seems to have to be an event that is overwhelming the health system per the FR document

Document.Description: Modifies Medicare payment rules for COVID-19 in order to assist health Medicare providers in applying "innovated uses of technology and capacity" that "might... be effective in the efforts to mitigate the impact of the pandemic on Medicare beneficiaries." Specifically, the rule allows Telehealth on a greater basis; alters the payment policies for independent laboratories; and expanding the locations to which Medicare covers ambulance transports under Medicare Part B. The rule also amends Medicaid home health regulations to allow licensed practitioners to order home health services for the public health emergency. Notably, the rule does not  modify arrangements to give hospitals broader flexibilities to provide hospital services outside of the hospital.
File: Medicare and Medicaid Programs; Policy and Regulatory Revisions in Response to the COVID–19 Public Health Emergency
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Regulations..Relevant.Chapter..Section.o: * § 1834(m) - Payment for Medicare Telehealth Services (including billing codes)

Document.Description: This directive outlines US national policy for managing scientific, technological, and engineering information derived from federally-funded research at various institutions. "Fundamental research", as defined by this directive, is basic and broadly applicable scientific research. This directive emphasizes that such fundamental research should remain unrestricted, unless there are national security concerns that require it to be classified. Research projects should be reviewed for classification before federal grants are awarded.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Defense

Entity.Empowered: National Science Foundation

Document.Description: This directive outlines the National Strategy for Public Health and Medical Preparedness in the US, aiming to protect public health during disasters. It defines key terms, provides background on the US healthcare system, and establishes preparedness policies. It focuses on biosurveillance, countermeasure distribution, mass casualty care, and community resilience. It also emphasizes the need for coordination between different levels of government.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Defense

Describe.Health.Emergency: Does not require an emergency to receive financial contributions under the EMA program; however, EMA funds may be redirected in cases of an emergency or major disaster.

Document.Description: This memorandum addresses long term affects of COVID-19, emphasizing the need for a comprehensive response. It delegates HHS to coordinate government-wide responses to the pandemic and calls for the development of a a National Research Action Plan on COVID long term and the fostering of new treatments and care models. It also emphasizes the need for support services and mental health care, and requires the HHS to publish a report on how the various federal agencies can offer support to those heavily impacted by the pandemic.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services

Document.Description: Federal Disaster Assistance - Emergency Assistance
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency
Describe.Health.Emergency: An "emergency" is any occasion where the president deems that federal assistance is necessary to supplement State and local efforts and capabilities to protect public health and safety. A "major disaster" is a natural catastrophe which "causes damage of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant major disaster assistance....," as further articulated by the regulations.
Funding.Stream.Description: Funding for emergency assistance (more limited than major disaster declaration)

Document.Description: Quarantine, Inspection, Licensing - Interstate Quarantine
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Triggering.Event: PHSA Emergency Declaration,Health Emergency,Potential Public Health Emergency
Describe.Health.Emergency: Any communicable disease which is: (1) determined by the Director of HHS to have "significant potential for regional, national, or international communicable disease spread or that is highly likely to cause death or serious illness if not properly controlled"; any PHSA emergency declared disease; any communicable disease that the WHO has declared a Public Health Emergency of International Concern under Articles, 6 and 7, 12, 15, or 16.
42 CFR Part 70 (up to date as of 8-16-2024).pdf (https://v5.airtableusercontent.com/v3/u/32/32/1725645600000/evF8m_WvFWuNENv4eUpE-w/4vAan2bAeGK0IOBRjIpjxrn8IMFiXJeRqV-jq82rVWpvFuJ1-6SOtwa8zP4bHmKlQhZPMZNaeC5io8wdH4bbjS9FEuO_yIWa6HQNXQg_9Jf48LvCuAY6muMPZP0_uKrj-S4SOJdXDe8gdQtOBA_yhsPCBEmfPy3PryH8cxh1EwmENbQ_DBbxY5H5uPJXM8gk/gaWyZm9Zm9LFUU1lacWHLSLS6GJ00oCvL6M6G-sQjKs)
Funding.Stream.Description: Gives CDC the discretion to pay for treatment, subject to the availability of appropriations

Document.Description: Foreign Quarantine
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Triggering.Event: Potential Public Health Emergency,Health Emergency,PHSA Emergency Declaration
Describe.Health.Emergency: Whenever the Director has reason to believe that any arriving person is infected with or has been exposed to any of the communicable diseases listed in an Executive Order, as provided under section 361(b) of the Public Health Service Act, he/she may isolate, quarantine, or place the person under surveillance and may order disinfection or disinfestation, fumigation, as he/she considers necessary to prevent the introduction, transmission or spread of the listed communicable diseases.
42 CFR Part 71 (up to date as of 8-16-2024).pdf (https://v5.airtableusercontent.com/v3/u/32/32/1725645600000/Ki0SkmnZUmch9RdpiOC0XQ/Px4wR3NXEaKY2wL2okPcastRb0l6ejZeloBo_Rkz8TaZSXyDVcUgNSO0kJ9uToQCyHY85DNt08KWkCgCoF_jsFzbuoAa6fV01p_ec4CBEw1OcKYLw6Jf75qUrY79QC7H4z9DVLoYl67waQ4RedDO2SaHlNfJEwKFWybPlyN6yfxNA5iJKB8z7lu7F8bclzZv/bb7eGTFFCbPh5GxGYxyWsTbBx5v37XR2LKapxfsiHuQ)
Funding.Stream.Description: Payment for care and treatment shall be in the CDC Director's sole discretion and subject to availability of appropriations. Payment shall be secondary to the obligation of any Third Party of the U.S. under any other law or contractual agreement to pay for care.

Document.Description: Care and Services during certain disasters and emergencies - provides the VA with authorities to "furnish hospital care and medical services to individuals responding to, involved in, or otherwise affected by that disaster or emergency."; authority to regulate vested in Secretary of Veterans Affairs
Entity.Empowered: Department of Veterans Affairs
Triggering.Event: PHSA Emergency Declaration,Presidential Major Disaster Declaration,Presidential Emergency Declarations
Describe.Health.Emergency: Covered disasters and emergencies include: (1) major disasters and emergencies under the Stafford Act; (2) disasters or emergencies in which the NDMS is activated by the Secretary of HHS

Parent.Statute: Strategic National Stockpile and security countermeasure procurements
Document.Description: Requires the Secretary of HHS, in collaboration with Assistant Secretary of ASPR, Director of CDS, and in collaboration with Homeland Security, to maintain stockpile of drugs, vaccines, and other biological products, medical devices and other supplies in such numbers, types, and amounts as are determined consistent with § 300hh-10 to be appropriate and practicable to protect from a bioterrorism attack or other public health emergency.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Describe.Health.Emergency: Part of emergency preparedness more generally
Funding.Stream.Description: Provides funding and appropriations to maintain SNS

Parent.Statute: Strategic National Stockpile and security countermeasure procurements
Document.Description: Requires the Secretary of HHS, in collaboration with Assistant Secretary of ASPR, Director of CDS, and in collaboration with Homeland Security, to maintain stockpile of drugs, vaccines, and other biological products, medical devices and other supplies in such numbers, types, and amounts as are determined consistent with § 300hh-10 to be appropriate and practicable to protect from a bioterrorism attack or other public health emergency.
Entity.Empowered: Administration for Strategic Preparedness and Response
Describe.Health.Emergency: Part of emergency preparedness more generally
Funding.Stream.Description: Provides funding and appropriations to maintain SNS

Parent.Statute: Strategic National Stockpile and security countermeasure procurements
Document.Description: Requires the Secretary of HHS, in collaboration with Assistant Secretary of ASPR, Director of CDS, and in collaboration with Homeland Security, to maintain stockpile of drugs, vaccines, and other biological products, medical devices and other supplies in such numbers, types, and amounts as are determined consistent with § 300hh-10 to be appropriate and practicable to protect from a bioterrorism attack or other public health emergency.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services - Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Describe.Health.Emergency: Part of emergency preparedness more generally
Funding.Stream.Description: Provides funding and appropriations to maintain SNS

Parent.Statute: Strategic National Stockpile and security countermeasure procurements
Document.Description: Requires the Secretary of HHS, in collaboration with Assistant Secretary of ASPR, Director of CDS, and in collaboration with Homeland Security, to maintain stockpile of drugs, vaccines, and other biological products, medical devices and other supplies in such numbers, types, and amounts as are determined consistent with § 300hh-10 to be appropriate and practicable to protect from a bioterrorism attack or other public health emergency.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Homeland Security
Describe.Health.Emergency: Part of emergency preparedness more generally
Funding.Stream.Description: Provides funding and appropriations to maintain SNS

Document.Description: Emergency use of Department of Defense, Public Health Service, or other Federal Hospitals - limited to emergency circumstances if they do not have beds allocated to veterans
Entity.Empowered: Department of Veterans Affairs
Describe.Health.Emergency: Veterans are only allowed to use beds allocated to other facilities if there is an emergency. The type of emergency  is not specified but likely follows 38 U.S.C. 1725(f)(1) (like other regulations in this section), which requires: (A) when department or other Federal facilities are not feasibly available beforehand and attempts to use them would not have been reasonable; and (2) when care or services are rendered in a "medical emergency of such nature that a prudent layperson reasonably expects that a delay in seeking immediate treatment would be hazardous to life or health."

Document.Description: Contingency backup to the Department of defense during a period of national emergency - VA is authorized to furnish hospital care, nursing home care, and medical services to members of the Armed Services in active duty
Entity.Empowered: Department of Veterans Affairs
Triggering.Event: Presidential Emergency Declarations,Presidential Major Disaster Declaration,NEA Emergency Declaration,Act of War,Declaration of War
Describe.Health.Emergency: There must be a "period of war or national emergency declared by the Congress or the President that involves the use of U.S. Armed Forces in armed conflict"
Funding.Stream.Description: "[T]he [VA] Secretary, to the extent authorized by the President and subject to the availability of appropriations or reimbursements, may authorize VA facilities to enter into contracts with private facilities for the provision during such period of hospital care and medical services for certain veterans."

Parent.Statute: Judicial Administration - Bureau of Prisons, Department of Justice - Institutional Management
Document.Description: Regulations for Infectious Disease Management within federal prisons
Entity.Empowered: Department of Justice
Describe.Health.Emergency: Requires proactive steps by prisons to prevent infectious diseases and their spread

Document.Description: List of Essential Survival Items in case of a nuclear attack - major attention should be given to insure the basic essentials in case of such an attack
Entity.Empowered: Federal Emergency Management Agency
Describe.Health.Emergency: Requires proactive steps in case of a health emergency caused by a nuclear attack

Document.Description: Health & Human Services Supplement - Federal Acquisition Regulations System
Entity.Empowered: Department of Health and Human Services
Describe.Health.Emergency: No emergency defined; general contracting rules

Parent.Statute: Office of Personnel Management - Civil Service Regulations
Document.Description: Agency Authority to take personnel actions a national emergency
Entity.Empowered: Broadly applies to any relevant federal agency
Triggering.Event: NEA Emergency Declaration,Presidential Major Disaster Declaration,Presidential Emergency Declarations
Describe.Health.Emergency: A national emergency involves an "attack on the U.S.", it must be declared by the President or Congress; involves danger to U.S. safety security or stability resulting from national, specified circumstances; and requires a national program specifically intended to combat the threat to national security

Document.Description: Internet Openness - Delegations of Authority - National Security and Emergency Preparedness Delegations
Entity.Empowered: Federal Communications Commission
Describe.Health.Emergency: An emergency must be declared by the Chief of Public Safety
Regulations..Relevant.Chapter..Section.o: * 47 C.F.R. §0.387 Other national security and emergency preparedness delega- tions; cross reference - delegates authority to declare a temporary communications emergency to the Chief of Public Safety and Homeland Security Bureau

Parent.Statute: Emergency Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Program
Document.Description: Assistance program that addresses law enforcement emergencies. If a law enforcement emergency arises, states may apply for assistance from the federal government. It helps alleviate costs, like overtime, incurred by law enforcement, in response to a law enforcement emergency situation.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Justice
Describe.Health.Emergency: Law enforcement emergencies are "uncommon situation[s] which require[] law enforcement, which [are] or threaten[] to become of serious epidemic proportions and with respect to which state and local resources are inadequate to protect the lives and property of citizens or to enforce the criminal law.
Funding.Stream.Description: Provides funding to localities to mitigate law enforcement emergencies

Parent.Statute: Emergency Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Program
Document.Description: Assistance program that addresses law enforcement emergencies. If a law enforcement emergency arises, states may apply for assistance from the federal government. It helps alleviate costs, like overtime, incurred by law enforcement, in response to a law enforcement emergency situation.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Justice - Bureau of Justice Assistance
Describe.Health.Emergency: Law enforcement emergencies are "uncommon situation[s] which require[] law enforcement, which [are] or threaten[] to become of serious epidemic proportions and with respect to which state and local resources are inadequate to protect the lives and property of citizens or to enforce the criminal law.
Funding.Stream.Description: Provides funding to localities to mitigate law enforcement emergencies

Document.Description: Provides federal aid for state governments in cases of insurrection; allows the President to use the Armed Forces against "unlawful obstructions" and/or interferences with federal and state law; and allows the President to give proclamations to disperse. Includes Guam and the Virgin Islands as "states"
Entity.Empowered: Executive Office of the President of the United States
Describe.Health.Emergency: Requires insurrection, obstruction, or unlawful interference with federal laws.

Document.Description: Empowers the Federal Aviation Administrator to "prescribe regulations and issue orders immediately to meet" an emergency. The FAA interprets this provision as providing authority to close airspace to, or redirect, a flight that may be transporting passengers with a quarantinable disease.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Transportation
Triggering.Event: Natural Disaster,Health Emergency,Terrorism,Act of War,Potential Public Health Emergency
Describe.Health.Emergency: Gives FAA administrator discretion; the emergency must relate to "safety in air commerce" and be of an immediate nature.

Document.Description: Empowers the Federal Aviation Administrator to "prescribe regulations and issue orders immediately to meet" an emergency. The FAA interprets this provision as providing authority to close airspace to, or redirect, a flight that may be transporting passengers with a quarantinable disease.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Transportation - Federal Aviation Administration
Triggering.Event: Natural Disaster,Health Emergency,Terrorism,Act of War,Potential Public Health Emergency
Describe.Health.Emergency: Gives FAA administrator discretion; the emergency must relate to "safety in air commerce" and be of an immediate nature.

Document.Description: Provides the Transportation Security Administration Assistant Secretary with the authority to cancel flights in an emergency situation, as well as to issue regulations or security directives without notice or comment. TSA interprets this to include the ability to prevent international flights from landing in the U.S. if the flight is transporting persons with quarantinable diseases.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Homeland Security - Transportation Security Administration
Triggering.Event: Natural Disaster,Health Emergency,Terrorism,Act of War,Potential Public Health Emergency
Describe.Health.Emergency: Emergency must be such that it "cannot be addressed in an adequate way to ensure... the safety of passengers and crew" otherwise.

Document.Description: Provides the Transportation Security Administration Assistant Secretary with the authority to cancel flights in an emergency situation, as well as to issue regulations or security directives without notice or comment. TSA interprets this to include the ability to prevent international flights from landing in the U.S. if the flight is transporting persons with quarantinable diseases.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Homeland Security
Triggering.Event: Natural Disaster,Health Emergency,Terrorism,Act of War,Potential Public Health Emergency
Describe.Health.Emergency: Emergency must be such that it "cannot be addressed in an adequate way to ensure... the safety of passengers and crew" otherwise.

Document.Description: Provides the Federal Railroad Administration with the authority to order restrictions or prohibitions on railroad carriers in emergency situations.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Transportation
Triggering.Event: Natural Disaster,Health Emergency,Potential Public Health Emergency,Act of War,Terrorism
Describe.Health.Emergency: Emergency powers must be necessary to abate an "emergency situation involving a hazard, death, personal injury, or significant harm to the environment."

Document.Description: Provides the Federal Railroad Administration with the authority to order restrictions or prohibitions on railroad carriers in emergency situations.
Entity.Empowered: Department of Transportation - Federal Railroad Administration
Triggering.Event: Natural Disaster,Health Emergency,Potential Public Health Emergency,Act of War,Terrorism
Describe.Health.Emergency: Emergency powers must be necessary to abate an "emergency situation involving a hazard, death, personal injury, or significant harm to the environment."

Document.Description: Provides rules for the exercise of authority by the Department of Transportation
Entity.Empowered: Department of Transportation
